reviewText: First of all, this is no game but a virtual interactive book, and a very good one as a matter of fact.\nTo everyone who is interested in the behind the scenes of Portal 2, and how a development of a game works at Valve, you're in for one hell of a ride. I absolutely recommend it, it shows the everyday routine of an employee at Valve, some very enlightening points of view on their known delays and some videos plus slideshows too keep you interested while reading. If you read it all calmly and with some attention it will take you a bit less than an hour to go through it all, but I assure you, it's absolutely worth it.
voteText: 69 of 75 people (92%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText: The Final Hours is not a game (though can't you imagine one - set perhaps during the Seven Hour War, trying to escape as the facility collapses and the Combine invade the test chambers?), it's a book. It covers how Portal was created, the complex gestation of the sequel, and the personalities involved at every step.\nThe book is interesting, revealing a lot of behind the scenes info. You learn what a complicated business creating a computer game is, especially a Valve one, and something of the stresses involved. For even at a company like Valve, creating a game is hard work, and it takes its toll. The book makes what use of its computer nature as it can, embedding videos and interactive content. They do not add that much overall though - the pictures and words are what matter.

reviewText:
I will keep this review really short, as there's not much I have to say about this title.

This is a E-Book on the story of how Portal and Portal 2 were made, different versions of the game and games that portal is based on and what inspired the team.

This is a very interesting read and also a lot of the original concept for Portal 2 is also really cool. I highly suggest you buy this if you're a portal fan, cause you will love this book.

The only thing I dislike, is the awful scrolling, between slides. Doesn't really work.

Overall this is a must own for all Portal 2 fans.

Final Rating:
8/10 - Worth reading

reviewText:
Portal 2 - The Final Hours ReviewInteractive book and story on the making of Portal 2.

There isn't much to say about this to be honest, it's so very short, which is absolutely fine. I only picked this up because I'm a huge Portal fan and if there is anything Portal related on Steam, I want it!

The Final Hours of Portal 2 is an interesting read to say the least. This interactive story on the full ins and outs of Portal 2 was fantastic. It looks at what came before Portal 2, and the aftermath of the game being released to the public. There's plenty of exclusive material such as concept art and original sketches. Along with some interactive animation which was fun! You really won't enjoy this is you aren't a big Portal fan though, so just make sure you've played the original Portal games before giving this digital book a read.

If you don't like reading, don't worry, it's not a novel, it's a very small read. But interesting nevertheless.

reviewText: This is such a treat! Portal 2 is one of the most visually beautiful games I have ever played. It tanks up there with Metroid Prime in terms of level design and ambiance. To have an interactive book show the design and art of the game is simply incredible. It shows how every step of the way Valve was cautious about nailing why this game deserved to be made and ensuring it wasn't completed till it has its modus operandi. I'll probably end up reading it a second time in the near future. I highly recommend getting this.

reviewText: An interesting and provocative look into the development wins and woes behind the critically-acclaimed game Portal 2. The interactive bits are tons of fun, and there's a lot of behind-the-scenes material that really opens your eyes on the game design process, as well as how Valve Software works as a company. Buy this...game?...if you're a fan of Portal 2, a fan of Valve as a company, or if you just want to see what kinds of ideas and practices go into designing and producing a video game.

reviewText:
I bought this game along with Portal and Portal 2. I read a little bit of it earlier but I really read a lot yesterday (I was on a plane, hence the low playtime,) and even finished it. Portal 2 - The Final Hours covers the development, release and post release of Portal 2 inside of Valve. If you like betas, like the Half-Life 2 beta, this is for you. I also reccomend checking out The Final Hours of Half-Life 2. Look it up online and there is a free version.

What makes this so different, though? For starters, it includes interactive content. The second picture (Destroy Aperture) is my favourite, as you can use the mouse to destroy some areas in Aperture Laboratories! There is also music that you can listen to, like the songs that inspired the soundtrack of Portal 2, and lots of pictures. There are chapters and polls even.

I really like Valve games and betas, and I thought WHY NOT?" when I bought this. This is worth $2
date: even $5 or $10. The writing is great

reviewText: I'm sorry to say this glorified PDF file is of little interest to anyone looking to get a look at the creative process behind Portal 2. In fact, the whole thing feels like an incredibly convoluted internet ad. There is a 'Buy Portal 2' button constantly present on all pages, right next to the permanently visible link to the author's website. One page early on in this document has as many as 7 'Buy on iTunes' icons, as well as the text 'Song previews provided courtesy of iTunes'. After the splash screen, four pages of marketing material for the author, Portal 2 and Valve follows, only then to land on the document contents screen. Sometimes you'll come across videos that are available in the document, but then there are also YouTube links to Valve and Portal related videos. And guess what? not all of them are available anymore - they're set to private viewing only.\n\nAlthough it's mildly interesting to read about the varied backgrounds of some of the creators, and to get a glimpse at internal Valve projects, there is really nothing you can get out of this thing that you can't get out of the Portal's and Portal 2's excellent commentary modes. I sincerely think that this would have been better off as a free PDF download. But hey, it's only 2 euros, so if you feel like reading an extended internet article at the price of a full magasine, go ahead.

reviewText: Yes, it's a book, so if that's a deal breaker, you can stop reading now. But I actually really liked the book (despite how brief it was); I think it's a great insight into all the work and everyone who made this game, and this is the only way you can get that kind of exclusivity. It's kind of awesome. And it's only a buck, come on, that's worth it for me (it's 50% off in the Summer Sale). It might even be better than Future Press's Collector's Edition Guide/Artbook (which is also great and I fully recommend it), but that's a stretch.\nAnyways, TL;DR: if you like Portal 2 as much as me and like to read, go for it.

reviewText: Portal 2: The Final Hours offers insight into the history of Portal 2 and offers a glimpse at some of the things that go on behind the scenes in the true leader of gaming...Valve. Since 1998, Valve has continuously been the bleeding-edge body of gaming technology--not EA, not Activision, not Ubisoft, but Valve.\n\nThis interactive e-book offers a hands-on multimedia experience into what really happens during game development. Being an engineer myself, I know that Murphy's Law prevails--anything that can go wrong, will go wrong. Even the leader of gaming technology cannot break this law. Yet the ability to start from scratch after stepping back and saying this product sucks" is such a rarity to see in this day and age. This story offers a rare glimpse at the talent
recommended: and the decisions behind a multi-award winning product."
voteText: true

reviewText: This is an interactive book that brings the world of Portal 2 and Valve to life with in-depth reviews and previews of what is to come and how it was all made. It puts a new view on the company that has created an incredible game. It brings more information and puts more in-depth detail and feeling to how a game is made. When reading this I came to understand that there is alot to do when making a game. This book really was alot of fun to read and interact with. It has video clips that add more information to the game and to how Valve operates as a whole.This book will show you concept artwork along with production of the game.This book has music stages of the game and how that process came about.Its a creative way to read a book, that keeps you going if you have a interest in stuff like this.The overall book is well done but doesn't take along time to read through the whole thing. If you like interactive books with alot of detail to how things got done then this is a book not to miss.

reviewText: THIS IS NOT A GAME. If you are looking for a game, you'll be horrendously disappointed. I wish the Steam app or store had more flexibility with its identifiers, so as to not automatically label an interactive product such as this as a 'game.' It is basically an E-Book. IT IS an E-book, actually. Plain and simple.\n\nSo If you want a really cool behind the scenes pass to the creative environs of Valve HQ, as well as insights from the various contributors towards the conception and execution of a world-class game title, well, you have come to the right place. This book is quite informative and really enjoyable to flip through, despite being a generally light look, as opposed to deep overview. And really, my biggest complaint is that it starts off quite meandering and sappy, but if you push through the first introductions, it gets a lot more interesting. Verdict: [ 7 / 10 ]

reviewText: For those of you who might think this is a game, it‚Äôs not. I only got this because I was a little interested in the development. I didn‚Äôt realize how absolutely boring of a read this was going to be. It‚Äôs like if Portal came up to you and told you its life story without telling you how it was actually developed. I think to sum up what I‚Äôm talking about, it reads something like ‚ÄúTime to get up and go to our exciting job of developing. We were really excited about this one part of the game when it came together. It was an exciting experience developing this game.‚Äù I‚Äôd rather be reading all of the court logs from when the Titanic sank for amusement than read about someone‚Äôs thoughts on the development of this and not tell us how it was actually developed. Maybe I just skimmed over it too much, but this is all I got from looking at the thing.\n\nI don‚Äôt recommend getting it at all.

reviewText:
Buy this now if you think that you are going to buy this any time in the furture. This Book is filled with youtube links and polls that are going to get broken over time.

That said it takes a good look at valve as a company and the game making process. How come valve never make thier deadlines and how they come up with the best video game plots that are not based off massive books.

This is a must read for any fan of portal, half-life or any of the games series that valve makes. This Book leads you into Valve the company and shows how fraggle rock and young minds mix together to create the best game studio on the planet.

reviewText:
For two bucks, to be able to read up on how Portal 2 was developed, how Valve works behind the scenes, what their culture and employees are like; this is a good read. The combination of photography, video, interactive panoramas and graphic elements makes this a solid digital magazine.

It's ported from the iPad version, so the interface and navgation isn't best suited for a mouse. Some of the graphics are a bit pixelated when in fullscreen mode on my 1080p screen.

I say you can go ahead and buy this if you're really a hardcore fan of Valve and not an owner of the Apple-branded tablet.

reviewText: An awesome sequel with one heck of a story and atmosphere.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
First of all, this is not a game. Nor is it DLC or a mod or anything like that.

It is a sort of book.

Remember those things, Oh esteemed Review Reader? Those things with pages and words?

Well, this is kind of like that. Except that it's digital. But that doesn't mean it's a boring sort of ebook like your mother has on her Kindle.

It has all sorts of web content built in, like youtube clips and photo galleries and so on. It also has all sorts of other interactive bits, where, for example, you can compare the Aperture of Portal 1 to that of Portal 2, and pretty much any picture you see can be viewed in high-def.

You might imagine this is just some sort of book with bits of the internet pasted in at random intervals, but you'd be wrong. Not only are the pages and elements really well laid out (with the sort of quality and style you might expect from a big coffee-table book), but they are all really well integrated with the text. The author is talking about an early pre-beta concept for multiplayer? Then there's an embedded video with footage. Now he's interviewing the composer of Want you gone"? There are various work-in-progress versions of the song that you can play from within the book.

As for content
date: it's also great. The author was basically granted access to the studios for the duration of the making of Portal 2
recommended: and goes into great detail about the process of making the game. There's also some human interest
hoursPlayed: as it talks about the backgrounds of the various team members and subsiduary teams
voteText: how they got into the video game business and what they brought to the team. It covers all aspects of the game
helpfulPercent: from how the story was developed
votesFunny: music and even marketing.\n\nIt's also pretty decent value for money. I picked it up on sale for about 30p (~50c)
commentsCount: and I think it is usually about ¬£1.50 (~$2.00) which is not bad for about 2hrs reading.\n\nThe only con I'd have to mention is the lack of multi-platform support. I thought it was awesome that I could play Portal 1 and 2 on Linux without having to boot back into Windows
column16: so it's a bit of a shame that they couldn't make this multimedia ebook thing cross platform.\n\nBut other than that
column17: a fascinating read; reccommended for all Portal fans
column18: and even for those interested in game design in general."

reviewText: If you're interested in learning more about the Portal universe, the people that created it, and some extra stuff behind the scenes so to speak, then this is for you. reviewText: Mistook this purchase as DLC for portal 2, however its a good interactive book to read once you have completed the main games. Being a interactive book, it allows you to do many things and learn how portal 2 was programmed and how different features were either left out of the final game, or included into the final game.\n\nJust a reminder of those looking to buy this, this ISIN'T game content for portal 2, its a seperate interactive book which runs seperate from the main portal 2 game. Look carefully before you buy!
